title: Macron is already looking for a new prime minister
summary: While some are calling for the French president to resign should the government collapse, his entourage is hoping that he can represent stability in the political crisis to come. But only if he quickly appoints a new prime minister.

title: Is France at risk of a government shutdown?
summary: The fall of the French government, which could happen on Wednesday, would bury the procedure for adopting the 2025 budget. But several scenarios are possible to avoid a French-style shutdown.

title: South Korean president abandons martial law attempt
summary: President Yoon Suk Yeol on Tuesday declared emergency martial law, accusing the opposition of being 'anti-state forces.' The opposition quickly denounced the move as 'illegal' and called on the public to gather in protest.

title: Syria rebels 'at gates' of central city Hama
summary: The United Nations says nearly 50,000 people have been displaced by the fighting since it began last Wednesday. The sudden flare-up in the more than decade-old civil war in Syria drew appeals for de-escalation from across the international community.

title: 'Trump's trademark is his hostility to government institutions'
summary: The choices of those who will fill the Trump administration show that competence prevails in strategic areas, but they are erratic on domestic policy issues, analyzes historian François Godement in an op-ed for Le Monde.

title: What it took to rebuild Notre-Dame within five years
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (1/5). Partially destroyed by a fire on April 15, 2019, Emmanuel Macron promised the cathedral would be rebuilt within five years. Due to reopen on December 7, Le Monde looks back on the five years that made this challenge possible.

title: California man charged with shipping weapons to North Korea, said they were for a surprise attack on South Korea
summary: Shenghua Wen, 41, was arrested at his home in Ontario, California and charged with conspiring to violate federal law barring the shipments. He said he was wired $2 million and told investigators that also tried to buy uniforms to disguise North Korean soldiers for the attack.

title: Macron announces France-Saudi partnership to co-host conference on creating Palestinian state
summary: The French president said that the conference would take place in June 2025 and highlighted the need for diplomatic initiatives to achieve mutual recognition between Israel and Palestine.

title: Zelensky pleads for Ukraine NATO membership, Europeans look for another solution
summary: Antonio Costa, the new president of the European Council, and Kaja Kallas, the new head of European diplomacy, visited Kyiv on Sunday, as soon as they took office. NATO foreign ministers are due to meet in Brussels on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: France and Saudi Arabia sign nine cultural cooperation contracts
summary: Far from the billion euros hoped for in 2019, the Saudi-funded heritage fund now stands at just €50 million, all of it earmarked for Paris's Centre Pompidou.

title: Trump to attend Notre-Dame's reopening in a diplomatic coup for Macron
summary: The American president-elect chose France for his first trip abroad. He will be in Paris on Saturday, December 7.

title: Bolivian ex-president who fled to US sentenced to six years prison
summary: The Supreme Court found the 94-year-old guilty of 'anti-economic conduct' and 'breach of duty' on Monday over the awarding of around 100 contracts for oil exploration and commercialization when he was president.

title: Why the Islamist rebels' capture of Aleppo is an embarrassing setback for Russia
summary: Russian air strikes have failed to keep Damascus in control of Aleppo. Moscow's priority is Ukraine, not support for Bashar al-Assad's regime.

title: World's top arms producers see revenues rise amid wars and regional tensions
summary: The United States, home to 41 of the world's top 100 arms manufacturers, dominates the global defense industry, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.

title: Aid deliveries for Palestinian refugees suspended through key crossing, following humanitarians deaths
summary: Two humanitarian workers were killed in the enclave on Saturday, November 30. Lack of security has forced UNRWA to halt aid at the crossing point between southern Gaza and Israel.

title: Finnish authorities say new cable cuts accidental
summary: Nordic digital infrastructure provider GlobalConnect told AFP two land-based optic fiber cables connecting Finland and Sweden had been severed on Monday in Finland, causing a 'major outage,' with 6,000 households and around 100 companies affected.

title: Norway extends legal limit for abortion to 18 weeks
summary: Currently, women in Norway can have an abortion after the 12th week but only with the approval of a medical committee.

title: Budget 2025: what happens without a Social Security budget?
summary: The left and the far right presented motions of no confidence against the government after Prime Minister Michel Barnier pushed his budget bill through without a vote on Monday. The lack of a social security financing plan could have consequences for France's healthcare and benefits system.

title: In Marseille, young footballers are overtrained in the hope of becoming the next Mbappé
summary: Driven by parents who dream of them becoming stars, an increasing number of children are following intense individual training programs with private coaches.

title: Trump cites Hunter Biden pardon in seeking hush money case dismissal
summary: President Biden announced Sunday that he was pardoning his son for gun and tax convictions. Trump was found guilty in May of 34 counts of falsifying business records from covering up the payment of $130,000 to porn star Stormy Daniels to silence her from coming forward about an alleged extramarital affair during the 2016 election.

title: How al-Qaida's ex-branch, HTC, is trying to smooth out its image to position itself in the conquest of power in Syria
summary: The armed group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which now defines itself as a Syrian revolutionary Islamist movement, is at the forefront of the conquest of Aleppo and wants to make a pledge to be removed from the lists of terrorist organizations.

title: Jaguar's spectacular strategic shift to appeal to the super-rich
summary: The British brand, now positioned at the very top end of the market, will be launching electric models with deliberately controversial styling, priced at over €120,000.

title: What will the post-Tavares era look like for Stellantis?
summary: The Portuguese boss left a deep imprint on the French-Italian-American group. After his ouster, what kind of structure, teams and outlook are emerging for the world's fourth-largest automaker?

title: 'French PM Barnier became the unfortunate guinea pig of an ungovernable Assemblée Nationale'
summary: The distrust that has permeated at all levels of the political spectrum since the prime minister's appointment explains the vote of no-confidence he faces, writes Le Monde's political columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Saudi Arabia: MBS's futuristic projects struggle with setbacks
summary: NEOM, the urban hub of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 economic and social transformation plan, is plagued by delays, cost overruns and resignations.

title: Philippines says China Coast Guard fired water cannon, 'sideswiped' government vessel
summary: Tensions between Manila and Beijing in the South China Sea escalated last month when Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos signed two laws defining the country's sea waters and imposing fixed lanes for foreign ships. This prompted China to summon the Philippine ambassador.

title: Proba-3, a satellite duo that will simulate an eclipse of the sun
summary: On December 4, the European Space Agency will launch two spacecraft from India on a 'demonstration mission' that will reveal the sun's corona, or atmosphere.
